Text: 2/2 enslaved people, tortured them and sold them like cattle. This is a petition to have Edward Colston’s statue removed from Bristol city centre. It may be historic but there are plenty of other ways to learn about it
540000 population of Bristol 10000 signatures. I really do hate, and I mean hate to do this but if you move the #colston statue to a museum you're brushing this out of the public forum.
Let’s sack off the Edward Colston statue - sign petition here http://chng.it/8VgKkwQQ via @UKChange

For anyone wondering who Edward Colston is, he's an 18th Century Bristolian slave trader. A lot of Bristol's wealth was made through the slave trade and his statue, shown to the left in this photo, is still in Bristol city centre. Lots of bits of Bristol are named after him.

So there’s a statue to Edward Colston in Bristol - One of the most powerful slave traders in Britain: 85,000 Africans were kidnapped and enslaved while he was running the Royal Africa Company. Can somebody in Bristol put a dustbin on his head please ? #Bristol

There is a statue of a slave trader in the city centre of my hometown Bristol City Council: Remove the Edward Colston statue in Bristol City Centre - Sign the Petition! http://chng.it/pT2db6g2 via @UKChange
Can't be long before left wing fascists demand 4 year olds masturbate over Colston's statue.

@MarvinJRees @BristolCouncil can we convert the #colston statue to a urinal please? Just drag it onto its back with a HIAB and stick some of those portable urinals around it. Afternoons work, call it art. Will crowdfund if you agree.
Remove the Edward Colston statue and put it in a museum. https://www.facebook.com/100000660127027/posts/3273184749380164/

Anything from the past not commemorated with a prominent statue is forgotten? The statue helped hide the evils of the past. As recently as 2015 the Bishop of Bristol claimed Colston's slave trade links were "speculation". They aren't. His involvement is recorded in ledgers.
unable to attend the bristol protest tomorrow due to the virus and shielding friends, but i wholeheartedly hope to see the statue of edward colston torn to the fucking ground

Moving a statue doesn't erase history. It's the work done by local historians that's put attention on the statue and exposed Colston's true role in the slave trade that was being obscured by the great and good.
Bristol City Council: Remove the Edward Colston statue in Bristol City Centre - Sign the Petition! http://chng.it/FtJSRXyX via @UKChange

Isn’t time to (finally) remove the Edward Colston statue in Bristol City Centre (and I would add look at alternative ways of reflecting on our collective history as cities like Berlin have done so brilliantly) ? Sign the Petition! http://chng.it/msVCZDB5 via @UKChange
Bristol City Council: Remove the Edward Colston statue in Bristol City Centre - Sign the Petition! http://chng.it/zg6TkjQG via @UKChange #Bristol

I understand your point but to me that's "dead" history. Just another exhibit, more exciting things in the next hall would surely mean it gets forgotten. If the statue hadn't been where it is now I for 1 wouldn't have found out so much about Colston. Why is a statue in a public

From what I've read, the statue was largely the project of one man - JW Arrowsmith 170 yrs after Colston's death. It, along with the Victorian myth that surrounds Colston have little historical merit so moving it to a museum as part of the wider slavery story would be appropriate

We should not be celebrating a slave trader. Colston’s statue should be removed and put in a museum where his significance can be properly contextualised. It’s not erasing history. It’s 2020 and we can do better than commemorating someone like this.

What I never realised is that Colston's family left Bristol for London when he was a child and he didn't return to live in Bristol. And yet, through financial acts, he's held as a pivotal Bristolian figure. A statue, music venue, streets, schools and more named after him.
